Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Drought, Water And Sustainable Cultural Practices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers, the public, and governing agencies are increasingly concerned about how societies will sustainably manage precious natural resources, such as water, in the face of both increasing demands and climate change. Archaeology can provide insights into how communities confronted similar problems in the past. Under the direction of Dr. Christopher Roos, Michael Aiuvalasit will investigate how prehistoric droughts impacted the long-term sustainability of Ancestral Puebloan communities in the Jemez Mountains of New Mexico. This study is timely because the American Southwest is experiencing a drought of a magnitude and severity last seen by prehistoric Ancestral Puebloans in the 15th and 16th centuries. By integrating existing archaeological datasets and high resolution paleoclimatic data with new low-impact data recovery techniques at prehistoric water storage features, this study will provide a long-term perspective on how communities adapt to climate change. Science and history curriculum exploring the relationship between water, climate, and culture will be developed for students in descendant Native American communities in the region.

This study will serve as an example for how archaeologists can move beyond making simple causal links between changes in climate and culture by acknowledging the social dynamics that ultimately drive community resilience (or vulnerability) to climate change. The adjacent Jemez and Pajarito Plateaus in the Jemez Mountains provide an ideal context for this investigation. While these regions share similar physical contexts, climate histories, and prehistoric adaptations the cultural histories of these regions diverged during droughts in the 15th and 16th centuries. Large communities of the Pajarito Plateau were abandoned, while those of the Jemez Plateau persisted until the Spanish removed local populations in the 17th century. Drought has often been evoked as a cause for the abandonment of the Pajarito, but little consideration has been given to how this happened, or why communities of the Jemez Plateau persevered through analogous conditions. Water storage features, thought to be reservoirs used to hold domestic water, are found at large village sites in both regions. These features will be directly tested to reconstruct the use-life histories of these features, which will then serve as a proxy for understanding how communities took collective action to solve resource management problems. Using archaeological geology, hydrogeology, and predications derived from economic modeling, the responses to droughts by communities between these regions will be compared. Models of community water budgets and tree-ring based reconstructions of drought periodicities will be compared to when and how these features functioned to establish the contributions these features to overall community water budgets, and whether or not there were differences in communal responses to droughts between these regions. Formal cost-benefit analyses will be used to model whether the payoffs for participating in collective management of water were different before, during, or after droughts. This study has the potential to assess the relationship between climate change, resource management, and community sustainability using similar approaches to those used by social scientists who evaluate the vulnerability of modern communities to climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This interdisciplinary research integrated existing and new data on ancient climates, hydrology, and archaeology to better understand why between AD 1100-1700 Ancestral Puebloan communities of the Jemez Plateau in the Jemez Mountains of New Mexico were seemingly resilient to droughts, while those of the adjoining Pajarito Plateau underwent dramatic cultural changes and were ultimately abandoned. This is important because too often archaeological studies attempting to identify the causal linkages between changes in climate and culture are hampered by poor archaeological proxies for resource management, coarse resolution paleoclimate data, and few reliable archaeological population estimates.

The legacy of environmental and archaeological research in the region coupled with new archaeological investigations and analyses provided a fruitful opportunity formulate and test a series of hypotheses on the relationship between climate and culture in the Jemez Mountains. First, we hypothesized that dry periods identified in the paleoclimatological record would have been experienced as socio-economic droughts by Ancestral Puebloans. By integrating the existing geohydrological, and paleoclimatological data with modern analogs we developed a paleohydrological model. In this model we identified water resources sensitive to dry periods. Our study found that the hydrological systems of both regions are sensitive to droughts, but that the Pajarito Plateau is far more vulnerable, with 20% of springs and the majority of the intermittent streams susceptible to reduced discharges. Cost path analyses of water acquisition costs from archaeological sites to water sources found that while Pajarito villages are closer to water than those of the Jemez, they were often closest to sources vulnerable to droughts. When these sources would go dry during a drought the time differential to alternative perennial water sources is nearly double that for the Pajarito than for the Jemez. These findings support the hypothesis that dry periods were likely experienced as droughts in the Jemez Mountains, impacting water resource availability and acquisition times.

Second, we hypothesized that water storage features, or reservoirs, built at and near many large villages in the Jemez Mountains stored water for domestic use as a way to buffer against the risks of water insecurity. After attaining federal research permits and going through consultations with descendant communities we collected sediment cores from 15 reservoir features using low-impact geoarchaeological methods at Bandelier National Monument, Los Alamos National Labs, and the Santa Fe National Forest. Samples from sediments infilling the dug-out basins of the reservoirs and the earthen fill and buried surfaces below the artificial berms were used for radiometric dating, stratigraphic studies, and paleoecological reconstructions of water quality. These data coupled with geospatial analyses of LiDAR-derived surface elevation data allowed the reconstruction of when and how these features were used. First, the hydrological mapping and paleoecological record of water conditions from fossil diatoms in sediments show that these features likely held water for only short periods in the spring and during the fall after monsoonal rains, and therefore they could not be the sole source of water for these communities. Jemez reservoirs were built before the rise of big villages, from between approximately AD 1100-1300, and most were used through the entire span of village occupations. They showed evidence of being maintained, yet they would have provided only a relatively small percentage of a communities water needs. Pajarito reservoirs were built not at the founding of villages, but instead during the regional population peak at AD 1300. They showed no evidence of maintenance. All infilled and ceased being used by the mid-1400s, which was a period of population decline and repeated decadal-scale droughts. Ancestral Puebloans were heavily reliant upon these features to provide their water needs as an alternative to natural water, yet they built multiple reservoir features, which would have been costly to maintain.

Predictions from economics and sustainability sciences hypothesize that robust collective action strategies of resource management enacted well before resource stress are more resilient to disturbances (such as drought) than those founded during periods of stress. The chronologies of reservoir use and occupation support this hypothesis, but additional lines of evidence suggest a more complicated scenario. Dual residence patterns of village and household field house use appear to break down during the 1400s, with villagers instead living year-round in their aggregated pueblos. This over-reliance­ on collect action approaches, which developed during climatically wet periods, perhaps made communities of the Pajarito more vulnerable to droughts than those who maintained a dual residence pattern and were less reliant on artificial water storage, like the Jemez. Indices of water insecurity, linkages between water transport technologies and collective action strategies, and refined cost path analyses are being developed to further evaluate this hypothesis so that this work can serve as an archaeological example for modern communities struggling with ways to mitigate the risks associated with climate change.
